<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Two new Cd(II) coordination compounds, namely [Cd(Htci)(biimpy)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(tci)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(biimpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci = tri(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanuric acid, biimpy = 2,6-bis(1-imdazoly)pyridine) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> tuning the pH of reaction mixture. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a 2D layer structure that further extended into a 3D supramolecular framework directed by hydrogen bonds, and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> features a 3D pillar-layered framework. In these two compounds, the organic carboxylate ligands adopt two distinct conformations: <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The luminescent properties investigations indicated that both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> emit intense luminescence at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new Cd(II) coordination compounds, namely [Cd(Htci)(biimpy)]n (1) and [Cd3(tci)2(biimpy)2(H2O)2]n (2) (H3tci=tri(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanuric acid, biimpy=2,6-bis(1-imdazoly)pyridine) were synthesized under solvothermal conditions via tuning the pH of reaction mixture. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compound 1 features a 2D layer structure that further extended into a 3D supramolecular framework directed by hydrogen bonds, and compound 2 features a 3D pillar-layered framework. In these two compounds, the organic carboxylate ligands adopt two distinct conformations: cis-cis-trans for 1 and cis-cis-cis for 2. The luminescent properties investigations indicated that both 1 and 2 emit intense luminescence at room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ pH induced two new Cd(II) compounds.   ⋅ These two compounds display two different frameworks.   ⋅ These two compounds emit intense luminescence.   

pH induced two new Cd(II) compounds.

These two compounds display two different frameworks.

These two compounds emit intense luminescence.

Introduction

The self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands into coordination compounds have received more and more attention because the coordination compounds not only feature intriguing topological frameworks but also can be used as functional materials in the fields of luminescence, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and separation, sensing and so on []. However, the controllable self-assembly of coordination compounds is still a huge challenge for obtaining the desired structures with unique physical and chemical properties since there exist many factors, such as the coordination geometry of metal ions, the conformation of the flexible organic ligand, the pH of the reaction mixture, template, counterion and so on, that can significantly affect the structural diversity of the coordination compounds []. Therefore, it is very important for us to understand the relationship between the structures of the compounds and the various stimuli. On the other hand, the selection of an appropriate organic ligand also can help us to construct the desired structures. Generally speaking, organic multicarboxylate ligands are the first choice for the construction of coordination compounds because they are sensitive to pH of the reaction solution and can adopt variety of coordination modes to bridge metal ions []. Compared to the rigid tricarboxylate ligands, such as 1, 3, 5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and 1, 3, 5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene, the tripodal symmetrical tri(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanuric acid (H3tci) has three highly flexible carboxylate arms (CH2 CH2 COOH), which may makes them adopt two different conformations (cis-cis-trans and cis-cis-cis) and three different forms of existence (H2tci-, Htci2- and tci3-) in the coordination compounds []. Up to now, lots of tci-based coordination compounds have been documented, in view of its prominent structural feature, new functional coordination compounds based on H3tci still need us to develop. In this work, we selected H3tci as the organic building block to assemble with Cd(II) ions. Via tuning the pH of reaction mixture, we successfully obtained two new Cd(II) compounds, namely [Cd(Htci)(biimpy)]n (1) and [Cd3(tci)2(biimpy)2(H2O)2]n (2) (H3tci=tri(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanuric acid, biimpy=2,6-bis(1-imdazoly)pyridine). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compound 1 is a 2D layer structure and compound 2 is a 3D pillar-layered framework.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">All reagents and solvents employed in this work were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were determined with an elemental Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra using the KBr pellets were measured on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro powder diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a NETSCHZ STA–449C thermo-analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen flow of 5 mL/min. Fluorescence spectra of the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out on Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and instrumentation

All reagents and solvents employed in this work were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were determined with an elemental Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra using the KBr pellets were measured on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400-4000cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro powder diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermo-analyzer with a heating rate of 10°C/min under a nitrogen flow of 5mL/min. Fluorescence spectra of the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out on Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer.

Synthesis of compound [Cd(Htci)(biimpy)]n 

In a 23mL Teflon lined stainless steel container, Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.2mmol, 0.06g), H3tci (0.034g, 0.1mmol) and biimpy (0.021g, 0.1mmol) were dissolved in 10mLH2O, and then adjust the pH to 6.0 using 0.2mL 1mol/L NaOH solution. Then, the mixture was heated to 120°C and held at this temperature for 72h. After cooling slowly to the room temperature, yellow prism crystals were obtained in 38% yield. Anal. Calc. for 1 C23H21CdN8O9: C, 41.45; H, 3.15; N, 16.82. Found: C, 41.53; H, 3.12; N, 16.87. IR/cm-1(KBr): 3412 (m), 1615 (s), 1592 (s), 1548 (s), 1516 (m), 1428 (m), 1367 (s), 1261 (m), 1227 (s), 1072 (w), 967 (m), 845 (m), 772 (w), 746 (w), 653 (w).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Suitable single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed with a computer–controlled Oxford Xcalibu E diffractometer with graphite–monochromated Mo–K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program []. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full–matrix least–square methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by using the SHELXL–97 program package []. All non–hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to their parent atoms of organic ligands were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>, selected bond lengths and angles are given in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1-2 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed with a computer-controlled Oxford Xcalibu E diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at T=293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program []. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-square methods on F 2 by using the SHELXL-97 program package []. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to their parent atoms of organic ligands were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of 1-2 are summarized in  , selected bond lengths and angles are given in .

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallized in monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/c space group with the asymmetric unit containing one Cd(II) ion, one Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a, the Cd(II) ion is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N8 and N4a) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O8, O9, O6c, O7b and O7b) from three different Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, affording a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N distances are in the range of 2.302(3)-2.544(3) Å, 2.266(3)-2.270(3) Å, respectively. In the self-assemble process, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, and the Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation linking three different Cd(II) ions in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O,O′), (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O″,O‴), O‴ coordination mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>a). Two symmetry-related Cd(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups into a dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 3.897 Å. Under the synergetic bridging effect of Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and biimpy ligands, the dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits are bridged together into a 2D layer (b). In this 2D layer, each dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit is connected to six adjacent identical ones <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> four biimpy ligands and four Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (each two Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands links two dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits). Topologically speaking, the dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, so this 2D layer represents a 6-connected 2D <ce:italic>hxl</ce:italic> plane topological network with the point symbol of {3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>,4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>,5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} (c). Notably, there exist abundant hydrogen bonds between C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H groups and O donors, which not only further consolidate the 2D layer but also extend the 2D layer into 3D supramolecular framework. The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of compound 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallized in monoclinic P21/c space group with the asymmetric unit containing one Cd(II) ion, one Htci2- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  a, the Cd(II) ion is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N8 and N4a) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O8, O9, O6c, O7b and O7b) from three different Htci2- ligands, affording a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The CdO and CdN distances are in the range of 2.302(3)-2.544(3) Å, 2.266(3)-2.270(3) Å, respectively. In the self-assemble process, the H3tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci2-, and the Htci2- ligand adopts a cis-cis-trans conformation linking three different Cd(II) ions in μ 3-(η 2-O,O'), (η 2-O",O‴), O‴ coordination mode ( a). Two symmetry-related Cd(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups into a dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 3.897Å. Under the synergetic bridging effect of Htci2- and biimpy ligands, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits are bridged together into a 2D layer (b). In this 2D layer, each dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit is connected to six adjacent identical ones via four biimpy ligands and four Htci2- ligands (each two Htci2- ligands links two dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits). Topologically speaking, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, so this 2D layer represents a 6-connected 2D hxl plane topological network with the point symbol of {36,46,53} (c). Notably, there exist abundant hydrogen bonds between CH groups and O donors, which not only further consolidate the 2D layer but also extend the 2D layer into 3D supramolecular framework. The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in .

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0065">Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:italic>Via</ce:italic> tuning the pH value of reaction mixture, another new compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallized in the triclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 space group, and contains one and half Cd(II) ions, one tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>b, the Cd1 ion is coordinated by two nitrogen donors (N4 and N8b) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen donors (O8, O9, O6b, O7b and O8c) from three different tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, adopting a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, and the Cd2 ion is four-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen donors (O4, O5 and O7a) from two independent tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O1w), displaying a rare tetrahedral geometry. The Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N distances locate in the range of 2.087(7)–2.619(5) Å, 2.253(5)–2.296(4) Å, respectively. Different from compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand deprotonated three protons into tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, and the tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> conformation and exhibits a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O,O′),O′, (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O″,O‴), O″, (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O‴′,O‴″) coordination mode (b). The tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand using its carboxylate groups links the Cd(II) ions to form a 2D layer (b). These adjacent 2D layers are further pillared by the biimpy ligands, giving rise to a 3D pillar-layered framework (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of compound 2 

 Via tuning the pH value of reaction mixture, another new compound 2 was obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallized in the triclinic P-1 space group, and contains one and half Cd(II) ions, one tci3- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  b, the Cd1 ion is coordinated by two nitrogen donors (N4 and N8b) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen donors (O8, O9, O6b, O7b and O8c) from three different tci3- ligands, adopting a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, and the Cd2 ion is four-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen donors (O4, O5 and O7a) from two independent tci3- ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O1w), displaying a rare tetrahedral geometry. The CdO and CdN distances locate in the range of 2.087(7)-2.619(5) Å, 2.253(5)-2.296(4) Å, respectively. Different from compound 1, the H3tci ligand deprotonated three protons into tci3-, and the tci3- ligand adopts a cis-cis-cis conformation and exhibits a μ 5-(η 2-O,O'),O', (η 2-O",O‴), O", (η 2-O‴',O‴") coordination mode (b). The tci3- ligand using its carboxylate groups links the Cd(II) ions to form a 2D layer (b). These adjacent 2D layers are further pillared by the biimpy ligands, giving rise to a 3D pillar-layered framework (c).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0070">Effect of the pH on the structure of compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The synthetic conditions of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are the same except the pH value of the reaction mixture. The pH not only can affect the extent of deprotonation of organic multicarboxylate ligand but also can induce different conformation of the flexible organic mutilcarboxylate ligand. During the self-assemble process, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, three protons into tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand adopted a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation and linked three different Cd(II) centers in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O,O′), (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O″,O‴), O‴ coordination mode. While in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand adopted a rare <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> conformation and linked five different Cd(II) centers in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O,O′),O′, (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O″,O‴), O″, (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O‴′,O‴″) coordination mode. The different conformations and coordination modes for Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> resulted in the structural variation from 2D layer to 3D pillar-layered framework. Thus, the pH of reaction mixture plays a key role in controlling the structures of the coordination compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the pH on the structure of compounds

The synthetic conditions of compounds 1 and 2 are the same except the pH value of the reaction mixture. The pH not only can affect the extent of deprotonation of organic multicarboxylate ligand but also can induce different conformation of the flexible organic mutilcarboxylate ligand. During the self-assemble process, the H3tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci2- for 1, three protons into tci3- for 2, respectively. In compound 1, Htci2- ligand adopted a cis-cis-trans conformation and linked three different Cd(II) centers in μ 3-(η 2-O,O'), (η 2-O",O‴), O‴ coordination mode. While in compound 2, tci3- ligand adopted a rare cis-cis-cis conformation and linked five different Cd(II) centers in μ 5-(η 2-O,O'),O', (η 2-O",O‴), O", (η 2-O‴',O‴") coordination mode. The different conformations and coordination modes for Htci2- and tci3- resulted in the structural variation from 2D layer to 3D pillar-layered framework. Thus, the pH of reaction mixture plays a key role in controlling the structures of the coordination compounds.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermogravimetric analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In order to confirm the phase purities of the synthesized two compounds, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed. As shown in , the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are in good agreement with the simulated patterns, which suggest that the as-synthesized samples are in single pure phase. In addition, thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also investigated under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, it can be stable up to 267 °C, and after that, obvious weight loss was observed owing to the decomposition of the organic ligand. The final residue of 19.95% may be powder CdO (Calcd: 198.28%) (). For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first weight loss of 2.38% occurred in the temperature range of 125–150 °C was resulted by the departure of the coordinated water molecule, and then, the skeleton can be stable up to 300 °C. When heating above 300 °C, continuous weight loss occurred until 450 °C, leading to the formation of powder CdO (Obsd: 25.02%, Calcd: 26.02%) ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermogravimetric analyses

In order to confirm the phase purities of the synthesized two compounds, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed. As shown in , the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns, which suggest that the as-synthesized samples are in single pure phase. In addition, thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30-800°C. For compound 1, it can be stable up to 267°C, and after that, obvious weight loss was observed owing to the decomposition of the organic ligand. The final residue of 19.95% may be powder CdO (Calcd: 198.28%) (). For compound 2, the first weight loss of 2.38% occurred in the temperature range of 125-150°C was resulted by the departure of the coordinated water molecule, and then, the skeleton can be stable up to 300°C. When heating above 300°C, continuous weight loss occurred until 450°C, leading to the formation of powder CdO (Obsd: 25.02%, Calcd: 26.02%) ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The solid-state luminescent properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as well as free organic ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci and biimpy) were investigated at room temperature. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand shows an emission peak at 425 nm upon excitation of 310 nm, which originates from π*→n or π* → π electronic transitions, and the free biimpy ligand is non-fluorescent in the visible range. Compared with that of the free ligand, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a luminescent emission band at 438 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 325 nm), and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a luminescent emission band at 455 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 325 nm) (). It can be observed that the emission spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have obvious red-shifts (13 nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 30 nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)with respect to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand. Thus, the luminescent emissions of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer. The red-shifts of emission spectra for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were caused by the deprotonation of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand and coordination effects to metal centers, which can effectively enhance the rigidity of organic ligand. In addition, the difference of emission peaks between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be caused by the different deprotonated existent forms (Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), different coordination environments for metal ions and different spatial frameworks [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 

The solid-state luminescent properties of compound 1 and 2 as well as free organic ligands (H3tci and biimpy) were investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the free H3tci ligand shows an emission peak at 425 nm upon excitation of 310 nm, which originates from π*→n or π* → π electronic transitions, and the free biimpy ligand is non-fluorescent in the visible range. Compared with that of the free ligand, compound 1 shows a luminescent emission band at 438nm (λ ex=325nm), and compound 2 shows a luminescent emission band at 455nm (λ ex=325nm) (). It can be observed that the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 have obvious red-shifts (13nm for 1 and 30nm for 2)with respect to the free H3tci ligand. Thus, the luminescent emissions of compounds 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer. The red-shifts of emission spectra for compounds 1 and 2 were caused by the deprotonation of H3tci ligand and coordination effects to metal centers, which can effectively enhance the rigidity of organic ligand. In addition, the difference of emission peaks between 1 and 2 may be caused by the different deprotonated existent forms (Htci2- for 1 and tci3- for 2), different coordination environments for metal ions and different spatial frameworks [,].

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In conclusion, two new Cd(II) coordination compounds with the structural variation from 2D layer to 3D pillar-layered framework were successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> tuning the pH of the reaction mixture. Luminescent properties investigations revealed that these two compounds can be used as good candidates for photoactive materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, two new Cd(II) coordination compounds with the structural variation from 2D layer to 3D pillar-layered framework were successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions via tuning the pH of the reaction mixture. Luminescent properties investigations revealed that these two compounds can be used as good candidates for photoactive materials.

The following is the supplementary data related to this article:

Synthesis of compound [Cd(Htci)(biimpy)]n 

In a 23mL Teflon lined stainless steel container, Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.2mmol, 0.06g), H3tci (0.034g, 0.1mmol) and biimpy (0.021g, 0.1mmol) were dissolved in 10mLH2O, and then adjust the pH to 6.0 using 0.2mL 1mol/L NaOH solution. Then, the mixture was heated to 120°C and held at this temperature for 72h. After cooling slowly to the room temperature, yellow prism crystals were obtained in 38% yield. Anal. Calc. for 1 C23H21CdN8O9: C, 41.45; H, 3.15; N, 16.82. Found: C, 41.53; H, 3.12; N, 16.87. IR/cm-1(KBr): 3412 (m), 1615 (s), 1592 (s), 1548 (s), 1516 (m), 1428 (m), 1367 (s), 1261 (m), 1227 (s), 1072 (w), 967 (m), 845 (m), 772 (w), 746 (w), 653 (w).

Synthesis of compound [Cd3(tci)2(biimpy)2(H2O)2]n 

The synthesis of compound 2 was similar to that of compound 1 with 0.4mL 1mol/L NaOH solution to adjust pH to 8.0. Yellow prism crystals were obtained in 42% yield. Anal. Calcd. (%) for 2 C46H46Cd3N16O20: C, 37.29; H, 3.11; N, 15.13. Found: C, 37.31; H, 3.08; N, 15.15. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3347 (m), 1618 (s), 1548 (m), 1516 (w), 1423 (m), 1395 (s), 1378 (m), 1254 (m), 1228(m), 1157 (w), 1072 (w), 986 (w), 825 (m), 658 (w).

As shown in

The Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N distances are in the range of 2.302(3)-2.544(3) Å, 2.266(3)-2.270(3) Å, respectively. In the self-assemble process, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, and the Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation linking three different Cd(II) ions in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O,O′), (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-O″,O‴), O‴ coordination mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>a). Two symmetry-related Cd(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups into a dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 3.897 Å. Under the synergetic bridging effect of Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and biimpy ligands, the dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits are bridged together into a 2D layer (b). In this 2D layer, each dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit is connected to six adjacent identical ones <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> four biimpy ligands and four Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (each two Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands links two dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits). Topologically speaking, the dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, so this 2D layer represents a 6-connected 2D <ce:italic>hxl</ce:italic> plane topological network with the point symbol of {3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>,4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>,5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} (c). Notably, there exist abundant hydrogen bonds between C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H groups and O donors, which not only further consolidate the 2D layer but also extend the 2D layer into 3D supramolecular framework. <ce:italic>Via</ce:italic> tuning the pH value of reaction mixture, another new compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained. In addition, thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also investigated under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first weight loss of 2.38% occurred in the temperature range of 125–150 °C was resulted by the departure of the coordinated water molecule, and then, the skeleton can be stable up to 300 °C. </ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The solid-state luminescent properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as well as free organic ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci and biimpy) were investigated at room temperature. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand shows an emission peak at 425 nm upon excitation of 310 nm, which originates from π*→n or π* → π electronic transitions, and the free biimpy ligand is non-fluorescent in the visible range. Compared with that of the free ligand, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a luminescent emission band at 438 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 325 nm), and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a luminescent emission band at 455 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 325 nm) (). It can be observed that the emission spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have obvious red-shifts (13 nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 30 nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)with respect to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand. Thus, the luminescent emissions of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer. The red-shifts of emission spectra for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were caused by the deprotonation of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>tci ligand and coordination effects to metal centers, which can effectively enhance the rigidity of organic ligand. In addition, the difference of emission peaks between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be caused by the different deprotonated existent forms (Htci<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and tci<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), different coordination environments for metal ions and different spatial frameworks [,].</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of compound 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallized in monoclinic P21/c space group with the asymmetric unit containing one Cd(II) ion, one Htci2- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  a, the Cd(II) ion is seven-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N8 and N4a) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O8, O9, O6c, O7b and O7b) from three different Htci2- ligands, affording a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The CdO and CdN distances are in the range of 2.302(3)-2.544(3) Å, 2.266(3)-2.270(3) Å, respectively. In the self-assemble process, the H3tci ligand deprotonated two protons into Htci2-, and the Htci2- ligand adopts a cis-cis-trans conformation linking three different Cd(II) ions in μ 3-(η 2-O,O'), (η 2-O",O‴), O‴ coordination mode ( a). Two symmetry-related Cd(II) ions are bridged by two carboxylate groups into a dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 3.897Å. Under the synergetic bridging effect of Htci2- and biimpy ligands, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits are bridged together into a 2D layer (b). In this 2D layer, each dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunit is connected to six adjacent identical ones via four biimpy ligands and four Htci2- ligands (each two Htci2- ligands links two dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits). Topologically speaking, the dinuclear [Cd2(COO)2] subunits can be regarded as 6-connected nodes, so this 2D layer represents a 6-connected 2D hxl plane topological network with the point symbol of {36,46,53} (c). Notably, there exist abundant hydrogen bonds between CH groups and O donors, which not only further consolidate the 2D layer but also extend the 2D layer into 3D supramolecular framework. The detailed hydrogen bond parameters are listed in .

Crystal structure of compound 2 

 Via tuning the pH value of reaction mixture, another new compound 2 was obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallized in the triclinic P-1 space group, and contains one and half Cd(II) ions, one tci3- ligand and one biimpy ligand. As shown in  b, the Cd1 ion is coordinated by two nitrogen donors (N4 and N8b) from two independent biimpy ligands and five carboxylate oxygen donors (O8, O9, O6b, O7b and O8c) from three different tci3- ligands, adopting a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, and the Cd2 ion is four-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen donors (O4, O5 and O7a) from two independent tci3- ligands and one coordinated water molecule (O1w), displaying a rare tetrahedral geometry. The CdO and CdN distances locate in the range of 2.087(7)-2.619(5) Å, 2.253(5)-2.296(4) Å, respectively. Different from compound 1, the H3tci ligand deprotonated three protons into tci3-, and the tci3- ligand adopts a cis-cis-cis conformation and exhibits a μ 5-(η 2-O,O'),O', (η 2-O",O‴), O", (η 2-O‴',O‴") coordination mode (b). The tci3- ligand using its carboxylate groups links the Cd(II) ions to form a 2D layer (b). These adjacent 2D layers are further pillared by the biimpy ligands, giving rise to a 3D pillar-layered framework (c).

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermogravimetric analyses

In order to confirm the phase purities of the synthesized two compounds, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed. As shown in , the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns, which suggest that the as-synthesized samples are in single pure phase. In addition, thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30-800°C. For compound 1, it can be stable up to 267°C, and after that, obvious weight loss was observed owing to the decomposition of the organic ligand. The final residue of 19.95% may be powder CdO (Calcd: 198.28%) (). For compound 2, the first weight loss of 2.38% occurred in the temperature range of 125-150°C was resulted by the departure of the coordinated water molecule, and then, the skeleton can be stable up to 300°C. When heating above 300°C, continuous weight loss occurred until 450°C, leading to the formation of powder CdO (Obsd: 25.02%, Calcd: 26.02%) ().

Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 

The solid-state luminescent properties of compound 1 and 2 as well as free organic ligands (H3tci and biimpy) were investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the free H3tci ligand shows an emission peak at 425 nm upon excitation of 310 nm, which originates from π*→n or π* → π electronic transitions, and the free biimpy ligand is non-fluorescent in the visible range. Compared with that of the free ligand, compound 1 shows a luminescent emission band at 438nm (λ ex=325nm), and compound 2 shows a luminescent emission band at 455nm (λ ex=325nm) (). It can be observed that the emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 have obvious red-shifts (13nm for 1 and 30nm for 2)with respect to the free H3tci ligand. Thus, the luminescent emissions of compounds 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer. The red-shifts of emission spectra for compounds 1 and 2 were caused by the deprotonation of H3tci ligand and coordination effects to metal centers, which can effectively enhance the rigidity of organic ligand. In addition, the difference of emission peaks between 1 and 2 may be caused by the different deprotonated existent forms (Htci2- for 1 and tci3- for 2), different coordination environments for metal ions and different spatial frameworks [,].
